column6: Two Worlds II Official Strategy Guide
column14:
This guide provides FAR less than you are expecting. The lack of detail is ridiculous. Let me give you two (of MANY) examples:
1. In one quest ("Black Candles"), you are supposed to deliver two candles. The guide tells you where to deliver them, but it just gives the general location. It does NOT tell you that you have to put them in a basket that is hidden behind a partition. So you wander around for a long time trying to figure out what to do, and then look it up on the internet. You wonder why you bought such an unhelpful guide.
2. In another quest ("The Transaction"), you must talk to a guy named Tongue. The guide says to see him "in the same house in which he tested your loyalty and skill." Yet it had been quite awhile since I had been there, and I forgot where he was. Isn't a GUIDE like this supposed to provide better GUIDANCE?

In addition to it's lack of specifics, there is also a lack of general information. For example, there are symbols next to the numbers on your gear. The (next to useless) manual that goes with the game does not tell you what those symbols mean. One would think that a game guide written by the developers themselves would correct that omission. Unfortunately, this guide does not. One gets the impression that the people who wrote the guide (and the manual) are just lazy.

column6: Turtle Beach Ear Force Z22 Amplified PC Gaming Headset
column14:
This is one of the worst investments you could make.

Okay, I don't actually remember when exactly I bought these, but I wanna say it's been a good 2-3 years. At first, the sound and the mic both worked correctly. There were issues with getting some of the functions to work correctly, such as making chat volume adjustable on the amp that came with the headset, and other things of that nature. Now, I'm not technologically inept. I've built my last two computers, and I'm more than able to install devices, update drivers, etc. At any rate, I didn't care too much because the headset itself worked, with pretty good sound, and the mic worked and was decent.

Then, maybe a year or so after having it, I built a new computer, and the mic stopped working. Believe me when I say that I tried everything. I tried finding drivers on the official site, unofficial sites. I tried using every USB port on my system (even though other devices worked perfectly fine). I tried looking up solutions on message forums and such. I even messed around with settings in my Bios. Nothing. I probably kept using the headset for well over a year without a working mic, just because I was too broke to get a new one (after all, the headset's sound still worked). You can see from many reviews that Turtle Beach will deny all responsibility and say the problem is on your end. So after some brief interactions, I no longer bothered with them. But do let me make it abundantly clear that I have NEVER had a single device, before or since, that wouldn't work on this computer, which I've now had for over a year. That includes my new headset that I just got today (different company of course), webcams, game controllers... just about anything you can think of. And that's considering I'm now on Windows 10. Still no issues with any other device.

I am never, and I repeat NEVER, buying a product from Turtle Beach again. If anyone asks me about them, I will warn against buying from the company. I suggest you do the same. Do not buy these. I don't know if I'm allowed to make a recommendation for another headset on here, so I won't, but there are actually good ones out there. Please read the other recent reviews of the multitude of people without a working mic or sound for no good reason.

Once again, DO NOT BUY.

column13: Great, but not worth the hype
column14:
The Horipad was heralded as the first true effort of bringing a pro MFI controller to iOS. It's a good controller, but no better than the others on the market. I was most interested in its D-pad, which has been reviewed as the best on any platform; it's just okay.

Testing with Garou: Mark of the Wolves (a classic 2D Dreamcast fighting game), the d pad required VERY deliberate presses to execute moves. This was not the case in the arcades, on the Dreamcast, or even on the Neo Geo Pocket Color handheld. It becomes tiring and frustrating to watch smooth swipes transfer to mis reads or slow movements.

The Mad Catz Micro actually fared better, but neither was good enough for even casual play, so both were returned.

Overall, it's still a solid controller, but the price and hype is not justified. Keep waiting for a true MFI controller, folks.

Paying to play with Bots, Hackers, and Idiots. If I had to sum up my WoT gameplay experience that would be it.

I played up to Tier 9 (10 total tiers). I spent a lot of time on this game before I gave up. Here is my final review of the game:

No matter what you like about this game they will change it in the next patch. Particular vehicles, classes, maps, whatever.

Don't even think about building up your arty. They nerf it over and over and over. If you were unfortunate enough to have rolled arty a few years ago then you pretty much lost all that progress as they took every single ounce of fun out of arty. What they do is change the game mechanics to your shot has a lesser chance of hitting, then they slow your reload and increase the time it takes to aim. You can literally do your homework while waiting for arty to reload.

Getting a good tank is a matter of luck. You might spend months playing a particular research line (as it takes that long) only to find out that there is a TERRIBLE tank in that line. One that will take months upon months of playing a tank you hate. You have three choices at this point 1) play another tank then pay (a lot: $20+) to convert your experience, 2) play through it. 3) Start another line from scratch. World of Tanks knows you'll eventually just get frustrated and pay your way through. WoT also uses patches to change the stats on vehicles. You might find a tank you really like but they change it so you will want to play something else. They absolutely do this on purpose. Why? To keep you moving up lines and buying gold to skip almost unplayable tanks.

The game is built to encourage people to buy gold. The model works for sure. But, if you aren't one of those people thats going to put money into every single round then don't expect to do very well. If you don't have a premium tank you don't make as much silver (money), don't get as good of match making (who you fight against) and your crew increases in experience slower. Pretty much, you can grind for months and get now where.

Micro-transactions are a huge part of this game. Don't expect to enjoy this game if you aren't will to pay and pay often. It isn't cheap. I have probably spent over $150 on this game so far. Now that I'm not spending more money on it the enjoyment level went WAY down.

Edit: for those of you who think you'll get to T10 then just play that, you're wrong. Those tanks lose money on average, so you're forced to play lower tiers (which only make a small amount of money), buy and exchange gold, or buy a premium tank.

column13: Don't punish the player for exploration.
column14: Although Dark Souls 2 doesn't compare with the first, it is definitely worth a play to anyone who thoroughly loved the first. Dark Souls 2 features almost completely identical combat to the first which means; dodging/rolling, backstabs, parrying, stamina management, and switching between one and two-handed attacks. Unfortunately, weapon degradation is back, but now it is much more apparent than in the first on account of how quickly it happens, but they repair at bonfires. Several other core-gameplay features have been changed, but the designers have kept it fairly balanced. Dark Souls 2 also boasts beautiful new graphics and cloth/character animations that is definitely a step-up from its predecessor. However, what keeps Dark Souls 2 from shining over DS1 is it seems to punish the player for exploration. In the first Dark Souls, the player was encouraged to explore the huge, intricately interwoven areas with the hope that if they died, they would be back at the safety ofa bonfire with only a lack of souls and a new quest to retrieve them. On the other hand, in Dark Souls 2, the player loses health each time he/she dies, and there is little promise of finding a shortcut back to the beginning of the level, thus deterring the exploration that made the first so great. If you loved the first, you'll love this one, but go into it with lower expectations than many would hope.

Rock Blast is basically an upside-down [[ASIN:B0009X978Y Puzzle Bobble]] where the bubbles--er, rocks rise at a more or less regular rate, and in Story mode you have up to five prehistoric pets that provide different types of help, as well as random interlopers throwing their own rocks into the mix. My requisite colour-blindness complaint: If you are at all colour-blind, this game will be misery to play well. Even though I see colour perfectly, some of the power-up icons nearly completely obscure the rocks behind them. Unfortunately, the DS doesn't have much room to work with in the first place, so there's really not a lot the designers could have done. On the other hand, the \\\pale purple\\\\\" rocks could easily have been made a bright pink instead, to contrast better with the darker purple.

Another minor gripe: Although there are slots to allow for multiple players on the same cartridge, the high score table is effectively useless, because continuing a game after losing a round retains the score from the prior level, so one person who slips ahead could potentially take over the high score table, just by being sure to lose each round (not even on purpose!) and overwriting the entire scoreboard from effectively the same game.

Overall: I'm not blown away by the game, but it's fun for killing time while waiting. Great if you find it used for cheap."

column14:
For the price, these earbuds cannot be beat. I don't own a Vita, I use these with my iPhone and iPad for both listening to audio and making calls. I have owned three pair now - one was abused by a friend, another lost, and this third one is being protected with fierce love. I listen to expensive "reference" headphones all the time for work. Shoving anything in your ear and expecting sonic purity is ludicrous. Rather, earbuds are what you slap in and take off with when you're going to be busy moving around, or cannot be encumbered by a better listening system.
For earbuds, they sound great. Not to mention, the passive noise isolation is top-notch. I mean, ultimately "passive noise isolation" is really a function of the rubber cup materials that one stuffs into one's ears. But the nice thing about these is that you really don't even notice until your significant other is in front of you screaming red-faced when you finally look up from your gardening. So they yank them out of your ears. Did I mention that the construction and quality of materials is fantastic? I am speaking from experience here, it takes a lot of abuse to break these, and durability is a massive plus with portable devices.

So why take a star away if I love these earbuds so much? Comfort. A ring that surrounds the backs of these was designed by a masochist. It is basically a metallic ring with a diamond-cut pattern. So if the device leans into your ear, say while laying down, the sharp edges really dig into your skin. It hurts. Also, the large size cups always have a ring from manufacturing that I find irritating in my ears. Would these issues keep me from recommending this product? Heck no. In a world of $100+ earbuds out there claiming to be the holy grail of sound, these cheap ones check all of my boxes . . . except one.

column6: Mpow® Dragon Slayer Wireless Optical Gaming Game Mouse Mice Adjustable DPI Function:1000-1600-2400-4000 for PC/Computer
column14: After reading several reviews on wireless gaming mice, I decided to purchase the Mpow Dragon Slayer as one of the most highly recommended of those that were reviewed. And at first, I wasn't disappointed. Fast, responsive, comfortable - it met my gaming requirements fully. I especially liked the adjustable DPI function. And then, exactly 30 days after receiving the mouse, it went wonky. After about 3 minutes of usage, the mouse cursor just got stuck. No amount of moving it on any surface would bring it back - until it was ready to work again, which ranged from two to seven minutes. During this "frozen" time, all the buttons worked properly but the mouse stayed on its spot on the screen so I know it was communicating with the PC. I tried turning it off and back on, replacing the batteries, moving the USB dongle to another port, even re-installing it (because there are no drivers for it). Nothing fixed its insistence on stopping randomly anywhere on the screen. Therefore, its going in the trash so its a good thing it cost under twenty bucks.  Edit: The company contacted me via email and asked that I accept a replacement device and consider re-writing my review. I agreed and the replacement mouse arrived soon thereafter. I insisted on using it for at least 30 days to see if the same behavior occurred. Before the 30 days were up, I noticed that the scroll wheel button was far too sensitive: a flick of the wheel engaged the "free scroll" feature, causing the webpage I was on to shoot off the screen. But I got used to that quirk and tempered my enthusiasm when trying to scroll back up from the bottom of a website. I also noted that the additional buttons could not be mapped to specific functions when participating in gaming. Other mice could, but not the Mpow Dragon Slayer Wirelss Optical Gaming Mouse.  Two weeks ago - at about the five-month mark in the short lifespan of this mouse - it reverted to its true self and began freezing and stuttering once again. Exactly the same behavior that the first mouse displayed. Nothing could bring it back to even the minimum performance.  Needless to say, it went in the trash. tl;dr- cheap price = cheap workmanship.

In this review ill be splitting it up into 2 Parts  Part 1 Performance & Controls.  Part 2 Should You Buy & Final Thoughts  Part 1. Performance & Controls - Im not going to be going into detail about what the game is or how it plays. If your reading this review you eather know what borderlands is or have played it before and want to take it on the go. As you know this is a port of a 360/ps3 game last gen. In order for them to make a portable version of this they had to make some sacrifices to make it playable on the go. The most obvious thing you will see are the graphics are no were near its consol counter parts but to be honest the Vita is no were near the power of a home consol that being said it still looks pretty good on the vita. Now when playing the game you will notice the game does not run no were near 60fps it runs around 30fps when I mean around 30fps I mean around its not a solid 30fps in boss fights and other locations it dips to 23 fps to 25fps considering how massive Borderlands 2 is thats still impressive for a handheld. Is it still playable at those framerates deff so but just keep that in mind wen playing. In order for them to get Borderlands 2 to work on vita at 30fps they had to make some sacrifices like in most areas there are only 5 enimes at a time which still works well and the enimes do not lay on the ground when they die they do expload do to framerate. Now moving on to controls if you played the Consol Borderlands 2 then it will take you around 2 to 3 hours to get used to the controls the hardest thing is the Analog Sticks are hard to get used to do to the fact they are  smaller then a consol controler. Since the vita has less buttons then a ps3/x360 you will have to use the touch screen and touch pad to countroll parts of the game is it bad no as long as you take it as a grain of salt. But like I said you cant just pick this up for the firsr time and start playing it will take some time to get used to. The first 2 to 3 hrs I felt like I was loosing fights I normally wouldnt lose do to the controls. To make the game even better they did include 6 dlcs not all the borderlands 2 dlcs by far but they didnt have to go out of there way to do that . Is it a Solid game on vita no not by any means but it is playable. When it comes to the Menus in the game thats were you can really see this game is a port is in the  menus the  menus in the game look really small. You will have to get used to that part as well and 70 to 80% of Borderlands 2 you will have to be in the menus when your pickin up new loot or badass ranks or even looking at  the map. On most areas it will take 30 to 60 secends to load an area wich is pretty long but agian you have to take in consideration how big the game is. If your in a hurry to pick up and play this may not be the game for you.  Part 2. Summary & Should You Buy.  The quick answer is yes 100% you should buy this if this is your first time playing borderlands 2 then I would honestly skip out on it and buy it on ps3/360 or new gen or pc. If you can expect the fact that its running on a handheld in your pocket then yes get the game its worth it. Now if your a Borderlands 2 Junky like my self who has played it on diffrent platforms and put over 1000+ hours into the game then yes deff get this game without a doubt its amazing that you can even take this massive game on the go. Despite all the flaws this game has its well worth 20 to 25$ in my opinion anything more would be asking to much. I honesty think most people who played this were way to hard on this game for its flaws sure it has flaws but who would of thought that a game like this you could take on the go wherever you are. You do have to remember it is a consol game that is supposed to be played on a tv  Sure its still ment to be played on a tv at home on a couch but man... poping your vita out and shooting and looting is just amazing. If you can expect its a port of a Home consol game then deff buy it you wont be disappointedat all. Is it the best vita game? No but this Vita game probably has the most content of any vita game easily 60 to 80hrs can be put into it. I already have 1000+ hrs into borderlands 2  on diffrent platforms  as you can see its my  favorite game of last gen I never thought my favorite game of last gen would come to a portable were I could play it any were. When you play the game for the first time and see how big it is then you will appreciate it  for what it is and be amazed it can even run on a Handeld.  you cant expect this game to run at any were near 60fps because it is on a handheld less powerfull then a home consol but even then it just blows my mind they got it running on a handheld as well as they did.  Not perfect not bad Just by the game. Borderlands 2 on the go!!! P.S I did forget to tell you it has Mp only 2 Player Co-op do to limitations of the Vita still impressive but I have not tried it since I never played Borderlands Mp I always loved playing it by my self so it may be more Laggy and worse frame rate just a worning. This game exceeded my expectations. Negative feedback from hardcore MK fans made me hesitate to jump in line for MK X. However, I'm glad I went ahead and bought it.

GRAPHICS 10/10: The graphics are awesome. For some reason, I expected it to be just a repackaged version of MK9. But I was wrong: MK X is a next-gen game, at least graphically. Even little things, like enhancements to the animations of Raiden's lightning and Subzero's ice, is noticeably better. The arenas are really great. I also like the interactive environments in certain maps.

FIGHTING 10/10: What more can I say? This is a Mortal Kombat game. The fighting has been impeccable since the beginning. I have no complaints about it. The characters are responsive, no glitches. As usual, the combo attacks and special moves are cool as hell. There's really nothing to add.

STORY/ACTING 9/10: This game takes place in the future (Johnny Cage has grey hair). It's interesting to pick up at this point in the characters lives. I like playing new characters and others not available in MK9. The storyline is as good as can be expected. In typical Mortal Kombat fashion, you sort of need some prior experience with Mortal Kombat to understand everything. But most players will get the gist.

My general assessment of this game is this: if you want a fighting game, you won't find one better. A couple characters are missing (Goro and Baraka, mainly), but this didn't upset me much. I'm satisfied with the selection as it stands. If you're a casual MK player, I think you'll be very happy with your purchase.

Starfox is a fun flight simulator for the SNES system. You control Fox McCloud through the behind the ship view and through the cockpit depending on the stage. The game offers 3 different paths through the game ranging from easy, moderate and difficult. Each route has different worlds and bosses adding a lot of replay value.

When I first played it I thought of an old arcade game like Sega's After Burner where you are behind the airplane/ship blazing a trail of destruction zooming by at 100 miles an hour. Starfox does not have the overall feel of speed that After Burner had but it definitely has the same feeling of adrenaline and excitement. The game will keep you on your toes and focused or you will be destroyed pretty quickly. Once you find the cannon power ups and more warheads the game is a blast to play.

I always enjoyed beating the game on the hardest route and seeing the spectacular ending with an overall score. You definitely get a feeling of accomplishment making it all the way through this game. The final boss's two forms are really cool to look at.

Starfox like Street fighter 2 is a game to be played on the fly. You can beat it in roughly 35 to 40 minutes and will enjoy every second of playing the game. Though the games graphics are old and outdated the fun aspect is still there. It is definitely one of the best flight games for the SNES.

column13: Well rounded wireless XBOX ONE headset but with a terrible mic
column14:
The PDP has a surprisingly hefty build, solid sound, and many fine details on the unit. The only thing really wrong with this headset is quite an important one: the microphone. It does everything else quite well - clear sound, comfortable, and has a durable build.

Great sound - dynamic, booming bass, and great for the games I've played on - NHL, Madden, and Destiny. I love that on the headset there is a dial to adjust whether you want the sound more towards either the game or the chat. Great when you don't want the game to louder than your teammates/party members.

Build - Very impressive. Judging from the pictures, I couldn't really tell if the headset had good parts or design. The design has the good parts that Creative would normally use - steel headset frame and soft cushion on the headband. The microphone is a gooseneck style, which can be pushed back into the headset when not in use. Very siberia elite-esque. The microphone has a LED light. On the rears of the headset speakers, you can see the board for the headset. I assume these are for the wireless capability,etc. Very cool when it lights up green. The design is great - the dial and the power push button on the left speaker makes good sense.

Though the sound, build, and design are all solid, the microphone is very lacking. It does work. But you have to really talk loud for your party members and nubs over the xbox network to hear you. I don't want to always feel like I need to yell. There is no microphone adjustment option. Did the quality control team over at PDP just didn't feel like testing it on the xbox party chat? The microphone just blows.

It's too bad the microphone is holding this headset back.

-The sides blink bright blue (I covered them with electrical tape and it doesn't affect the headset but stops the blinking completely)
-The mic is really sensitive to breath, so you may be moving it around for a few minutes to find the best position ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

"The Amazing Spider-Man 2," a fairly decent game, makes me wonder how much better it might have been if not for being tied to the release of the film. Would extra time and more creative freedom have made it better? Surely. Its faults are that certain aspects feel rushed. The story, for instance, inexplicably jumps from one random villain to the next without pause. You’ll be fighting Shocker in one mission, Green Goblin in the next, but there’s nothing linking the two. The narrative ends up feeling disjointed as a result. The side activities are also your standard fare of beating up random thugs, rescue civilians from a burning building/hostage car chase, or web slinging races – all feeling like leftover ideas from past games. What saves this game for me is the combat, and specifically the stealth sections that feel like the Predator sections of the “Arkham” games. Spidey’s 'Spider Sense' acts as a Detective Mode, and you can use Spider-Man’s abilities to web-zip across a room or crawl on ceilings to evade and take down enemies quietly. I also enjoyed the feel of web slinging through the city, though a dynamic day/night cycle would have been nice. Out of the 3D Spider-Man games I’ve played, and I’ve played most of them, I probably like “Spider-Man” (2000) best, followed by “Web of Shadows” (2008), which had a unique story and upgrade system revolving around the symbiote organism. “TASM2” ranks more in the middle. It’s a very inoffensive game; it looks pretty good, it plays well enough, it has a nice variety, and the stealth sections are a strong step in the right direction. Throw out all the senseless side missions (or make them meaningful) and create an original story that has a proper flow and you might have something.  --- 3.5 STARS ---

(2) Normally, I get a small delay from the controller to the game. With this, I didn't get any delay at all. So when I get some of my old games again I expect I'll be able to play them just as I remember, with no awkward delay after I press on the controller.
(3) The casing is economically made, which is what I expected. The slot grips the cartridge stiffly, and I still had to fiddle with the cartridge a little to get it to play properly, but once I got it working, there was no problems.

I'd say this is a good buy for the money. Not a perfect replacement for an original NES, but good enough to play games on.
